messages.msgSnippet: Hi Col. Hrisoulas, I was not refering to you. Nice to know who you are though. Looking forward to the book. John Stuart p eng, m eng ... list and maybe I
messages.messageBody:
Hi Col. Hrisoulas, I was not refering to you. Nice to know who you
are though. Looking forward to the book. John Stuart p eng, m eng

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Question about a small Tanto or??
messages.msgSnippet: Ummmmm...ok I ll bite..I will admit that I am rather quiet on this list and maybe I missed a few e-mails.... JP Hrisoulas, Col. NANG (ret) Bladesmith,
messages.messageBody:
Ummmmm...ok I'll bite..I will admit that I am rather quiet on this list and maybe I missed a few e-mails....

JP Hrisoulas, Col. NANG (ret)
Bladesmith, Metallographer, Researcher
Author: "The Complete Bladesmith"
"The Master Bladesmith"
"The Pattern Welded Blade"
Soon to be released: "Custom Bladesmithing: Tools and Techniques for Craftsmen".

-----Original Message-----
From: excelsiorilluminati <excelsiorilluminati@...>
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sat, 29 Nov 2008 7:38 pm
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Question about a small Tanto or??






Gordon, Those who are in the Nihonto community are aware of who is who
and it surprises me that someone who will not even identify themselves
questions credentials of a giant in the field. Sometimes people
speak/write without thought or research and may be forgiven, but,
rudeness never. I hope you don't let it get to you. I asked in an
earlier post for ID and was ignored and that leaves me cold.
The "Unknown Polisher"? John

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, ROBSON Gordon <robsongo@...> wrote:
>
> The position of the mekugi ana and its shape are not of Japanese
origins. I don't
> need to read more books. As a member of the NTHK's shinsa team here
in Tokyo
> and a director of the NTHK, I would say that I am in a bit better
position to know. If
> that sword were submitted for shinsa, it would fail as not being
Japanese.
>
> Gordon
>






[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Question about a small Tanto or??
messages.msgSnippet: sorry , my humor was not understood, and you are right about the shinsa, but i keep saying that it is japanese but not made the traditional way. it is a
messages.messageBody:
sorry , my humor was not understood, and you are right about the shinsa, but i keep saying that it is japanese but not made the traditional way.
it is a tourist item and most of the time there is something like a hamon and some jihada is also often seen.
they are less then the showa stamp blades.
but thank you for your answer, by yourself because i think this hole group jumpt on me for this mispaced joke.

christophe
----- Original Message -----
From: ROBSON Gordon
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, November 30, 2008 2:47 AM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Question about a small Tanto or??


The position of the mekugi ana and its shape are not of Japanese origins. I don't
need to read more books. As a member of the NTHK's shinsa team here in Tokyo
and a director of the NTHK, I would say that I am in a bit better position to know. If
that sword were submitted for shinsa, it would fail as not being Japanese.

Gordon

messages.subject: Re: Question about a small Tanto or??
messages.msgSnippet: Gordon, Those who are in the Nihonto community are aware of who is who and it surprises me that someone who will not even identify themselves questions
messages.messageBody:
Gordon, Those who are in the Nihonto community are aware of who is who
and it surprises me that someone who will not even identify themselves
questions credentials of a giant in the field. Sometimes people
speak/write without thought or research and may be forgiven, but,
rudeness never. I hope you don't let it get to you. I asked in an
earlier post for ID and was ignored and that leaves me cold.
The "Unknown Polisher"? John

in Tokyo

position to know. If

messages.messageBody:
The position of the mekugi ana and its shape are not of Japanese origins. I don't
need to read more books. As a member of the NTHK's shinsa team here in Tokyo
and a director of the NTHK, I would say that I am in a bit better position to know. If
that sword were submitted for shinsa, it would fail as not being Japanese.

Gordon

and ultimately his lot.

Rich

> > > Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Question about a small Tanto or??
> > >
> > > Patrik,
> > > Agreed the wood graining in the saya looks genuine and typical of that
> > > sort
> > > of work I have seen. The brass fittings do not look to be of Japanese
> > > workmanship, especially the lack of a proper and neat finish where the
> > > metal
> > > edges meet the scabbard wood. This is especially true where the handle
> > > butts
> > > up to the habaki. The lack of a facing metal piece to the habaki
> indicates
> > > poor workmanship. It may all be modern, but the proof of the
> pudding for
> > > the
> > > blade will be when you take the handle off and see the tang. Do this -
> > > remove the habaki and take good closeup photos of both sides of
> the tang
> > > and
> > > put them up. The blade is the typical shape of a Meiji tourist
> piece, but
> > > running through the images again I'm of the opinion that the
> koshirae is
> > > modern as it just does not have the refinement of shape that we
> expect to
> > > see in Japanese workmanship. So the blade may be old, but if it
> does not
> > > have a clear and distinguishable hamon it is nonetheless a "junk"
> piece.
> > > Regards,
> > > Barry Thomas
> > > (Melbourne, Australia)
> > >
> > > ----- Original Message -----
> > > From: Patrik Danielsson
> > > To: nihontostudy@ <mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com>
> yahoogroups.com
> > > Sent: Thursday, November 27, 2008 8:27 AM
> > > Subject: [nihontostudy] Question about a small Tanto or??
> > >
> > > Hello everybody, i bought this small "tanto" on an ad here in Sweden.
> > > Its feel really genunine, some kind of hard wood whith nice
> graining in
> > > saya
> > > and tsuka, on some places it looks like all the brass has been
> > > silverplated
> > > (can still se it above tha habaki on one of the photos), i have
> not been
> > > able to take the tsuka of it yet,but i gonna do that,(depending of the
> > > answers here :-)
> > > Can this be a "tourist" thing , or is it made for a child , women or
> > > something like that?, if someone have some info age or something i
> will
> > > really happy.
> > >
> > > The blade from grip (above habaki) to tip is 6.5 inches / 17 cm,
> and the
> > > total is 10 inches/ 25.5 cm.
> > >
> > > Here is some pictures of it:
> > >
> > > http://s74.photobuc
> > > <http://s74.photobucket.com/albums/i248/wellcraftantiqua/japan/
> <http://s74.photobucket.com/albums/i248/wellcraftantiqua/japan/>>

messages.subject: Re: Question about a small Tanto or??
messages.msgSnippet: Sorry to bring in controversy here, but Mr Siliacus... You may want to research the name Gordon Robson before you make such rude and obnoxious statements.
messages.messageBody:
Sorry to bring in controversy here, but Mr Siliacus...
You may want to research the name Gordon Robson before you make such
rude and obnoxious statements.
Also, I have yet to find a traditional togishi that will advise people
to use lemon juice on a blade (or even confidently call themselves a
togishi when not trained in Japan)
Sorry, but there are ways to reply to people in a civil manner, and
that isn't it.
If this were my forum, you would be an ex-member.

Brian

messages.subject: Re: Question about a small Tanto or??
messages.msgSnippet: If you ask this Group for opinions, don t be disappointed when they tell it like it is. I respect this group and would never tell them they are wrong.
messages.messageBody:
If you ask this 'Group' for opinions, don't be disappointed when they
tell it like it is. I respect this group and would never tell them
they are wrong.

Opinions are just what they are. And my opinion of you is not real
high.

Elliott

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Question about a small Tanto or??
messages.msgSnippet: hi gordon, you are wrong, read more books, because that is clearly were you get your knowledge this is tipical a tourist item, normally there is a hamon, and
messages.messageBody:
hi gordon,

you are wrong, read more books, because that is clearly were you get your
knowledge
this is tipical a tourist item, normally there is a hamon, and some jihada.
i am togishi and i have seen a lot of those, people wanted me to polish
them but i can not spent my time on things like that.
here in europe there are a lot of them and some of them are very nice to see.
so my advice look around a little bit better

c. siliacus


>
>
>
> The nakago is clearly not Japanese. As I wrote earlier, it is most likely
> of
> Chinese origins.
>
>
>
> Gordon
>
>
>
> _____
>
> From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]
> On
> Behalf Of Patrik Danielsson
> Sent: Thursday, November 27, 2008 5:21 PM
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Question about a small Tanto or??

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Question about a small Tanto or??
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Patrik, The nakago is clearly not Japanese. As I wrote earlier, it is most likely of Chinese origins. Gordon _____ From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
messages.messageBody:
Hi Patrik,



The nakago is clearly not Japanese. As I wrote earlier, it is most likely of
Chinese origins.



Gordon



_____

From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Patrik Danielsson

To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com

Thanks for the answers, i now removed the handle on that little knife, there
are some new pictures on the link.

ket.com/albums/i248/wellcraftantiqua/japan/

----- Original Message -----
From: Barry Thomas
To: nihontostudy@ <mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com> yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, November 27, 2008 12:37 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Question about a small Tanto or??

Patrik,
Agreed the wood graining in the saya looks genuine and typical of that sort
of work I have seen. The brass fittings do not look to be of Japanese
workmanship, especially the lack of a proper and neat finish where the metal
edges meet the scabbard wood. This is especially true where the handle butts
up to the habaki. The lack of a facing metal piece to the habaki indicates
poor workmanship. It may all be modern, but the proof of the pudding for the
blade will be when you take the handle off and see the tang. Do this -
remove the habaki and take good closeup photos of both sides of the tang and
put them up. The blade is the typical shape of a Meiji tourist piece, but
running through the images again I'm of the opinion that the koshirae is
modern as it just does not have the refinement of shape that we expect to
see in Japanese workmanship. So the blade may be old, but if it does not
have a clear and distinguishable hamon it is nonetheless a "junk" piece.
Regards,
Barry Thomas
(Melbourne, Australia)

----- Original Message -----
From: Patrik Danielsson
To: nihontostudy@ <mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com> yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, November 27, 2008 8:27 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Question about a small Tanto or??

Hello everybody, i bought this small "tanto" on an ad here in Sweden.
Its feel really genunine, some kind of hard wood whith nice graining in saya
and tsuka, on some places it looks like all the brass has been silverplated
(can still se it above tha habaki on one of the photos), i have not been
able to take the tsuka of it yet,but i gonna do that,(depending of the
answers here :-)
Can this be a "tourist" thing , or is it made for a child , women or
something like that?, if someone have some info age or something i will
really happy.

The blade from grip (above habaki) to tip is 6.5 inches / 17 cm, and the
total is 10 inches/ 25.5 cm.

Here is some pictures of it:

http://s74.photobuc
<http://s74.photobucket.com/albums/i248/wellcraftantiqua/japan/>
ket.com/albums/i248/wellcraftantiqua/japan/

Thanks alot

Patrik
.

i hope you did not pay much because it is not a quality blade.
take the juiche of a lemmon and wipe it over the cuttingedge until you see
a hamon normally it is there in these kind of blades.
after that clean the blade and when you are lucky you wil see the hamon
still.

christophe siliacus

----- Original Message -----
From: Barry Thomas
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, November 27, 2008 12:37 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Question about a small Tanto or??


Patrik,
Agreed the wood graining in the saya looks genuine and typical of that sort of work I have seen. The brass fittings do not look to be of Japanese workmanship, especially the lack of a proper and neat finish where the metal edges meet the scabbard wood. This is especially true where the handle butts up to the habaki. The lack of a facing metal piece to the habaki indicates poor workmanship. It may all be modern, but the proof of the pudding for the blade will be when you take the handle off and see the tang. Do this - remove the habaki and take good closeup photos of both sides of the tang and put them up. The blade is the typical shape of a Meiji tourist piece, but running through the images again I'm of the opinion that the koshirae is modern as it just does not have the refinement of shape that we expect to see in Japanese workmanship. So the blade may be old, but if it does not have a clear and distinguishable hamon it is nonetheless a "junk" piece.
Regards,
Barry Thomas
(Melbourne, Australia)

----- Original Message -----
From: Patrik Danielsson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, November 27, 2008 8:27 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Question about a small Tanto or??

Hello everybody, i bought this small "tanto" on an ad here in Sweden.
Its feel really genunine, some kind of hard wood whith nice graining in saya and tsuka, on some places it looks like all the brass has been silverplated (can still se it above tha habaki on one of the photos), i have not been able to take the tsuka of it yet,but i gonna do that,(depending of the answers here :-)
Can this be a "tourist" thing , or is it made for a child , women or something like that?, if someone have some info age or something i will really happy.

The blade from grip (above habaki) to tip is 6.5 inches / 17 cm, and the total is 10 inches/ 25.5 cm.

Here is some pictures of it:

http://s74.photobucket.com/albums/i248/wellcraftantiqua/japan/

Thanks alot

Patrik
.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Question about a small Tanto or??
messages.msgSnippet: Patrik, Agreed the wood graining in the saya looks genuine and typical of that sort of work I have seen.  The brass fittings do not look to be of Japanese
messages.messageBody:
Patrik,
Agreed the wood graining in the saya looks genuine and typical of that sort of work I have seen. The brass fittings do not look to be of Japanese workmanship, especially the lack of a proper and neat finish where the metal edges meet the scabbard wood. This is especially true where the handle butts up to the habaki. The lack of a facing metal piece to the habaki indicates poor workmanship. It may all be modern, but the proof of the pudding for the blade will be when you take the handle off and see the tang. Do this - remove the habaki and take good closeup photos of both sides of the tang and put them up. The blade is the typical shape of a Meiji tourist piece, but running through the images again I'm of the opinion that the koshirae is modern as it just does not have the refinement of shape that we expect to see in Japanese workmanship. So the blade may be old, but if it does not have a clear and distinguishable hamon it is nonetheless a "junk" piece.
Regards,
Barry Thomas
(Melbourne, Australia)

To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, November 27, 2008 8:27 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Question about a small Tanto or??


Hello everybody, i bought this small "tanto" on an ad here in Sweden.
Its feel really genunine, some kind of hard wood whith nice graining in saya and tsuka, on some places it looks like all the brass has been silverplated (can still se it above tha habaki on one of the photos), i have not been able to take the tsuka of it yet,but i gonna do that,(depending of the answers here :-)
Can this be a "tourist" thing , or is it made for a child , women or something like that?, if someone have some info age or something i will really happy.

The blade from grip (above habaki) to tip is 6.5 inches / 17 cm, and the total is 10 inches/ 25.5 cm.

Here is some pictures of it:

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Question about a small Tanto or??
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Patrik, It would be helpful to remove the handle and see what the nakago looks like. However, from the outside, there are basically two choices from my
messages.messageBody:
Hi Patrik,



It would be helpful to remove the handle and see what the nakago looks like.
However, from the outside, there are basically two choices from my point of
view: made in China, which seems very likely, or a poorly done Yokohama-mono
or cheap export sword from the Meiji period or later. Rich has supplied a
third option (modern export model) and has been far more politic than I. In
the future, I would refrain from paying money of such things. You would be
better off spending your money on some (more) books.



Gordon



_____

From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Richard Turner
Sent: Thursday, November 27, 2008 6:42 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Question about a small Tanto or??



Hi Patrik, my personal opinion is this may be modern. If it is a tourist
piece, I think it could be Shouwa period at the earliest.

Best wishes

Richard
